awd_titl_txt: Progress in Thermoelectrics - From Traditional to Novel Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports travel expenses and registration fees for invited speakers, undergraduate and graduate students, post-docs, and under-represented, female and junior faculty to attend and present at the symposium EQ01 'Progress in Thermoelectrics - From Traditional to Novel Materials' held as part of the Materials Research Society's 2022 Fall Meeting in Boston, November 27 to December 2, 2022. The meeting also has a virtual version scheduled for December 6-8. This meeting will provide opportunity to exchange research results, network and discuss topics related to research and education in the area of thermoelectric materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Symposium EQ01: Progress in Thermoelectrics -  From Traditional to Novel Materials, was held from Nov. 28th to Dec. 1st (in person) and Dec. 6th to 7th (virtual experience) within the Materials Research Society 2022 Fall Meeting. This grant provided assistance to a total of 22 participants (6 early career scholars, 14 graduate students, 2 undergraduate students). The symposium gathered broad participation internationally, with a total of 107 abstracts received.

 

This symposium topics covered the forefront in thermoelectrics and related research, from transport physics to device fabrication and applications. One focus area was advances in materials. Sessions in this area covered materials design, synthesis, and characterization of inorganic, organic, and composite materials. Emphasis through invited talks was placed on new strategies to guide materials design. Another area was the advances in applications of thermoelectric devices, including but not limited to new manufacturing techniques and design principles. Since accurate characterization of thermoelectric performance faces challenges when performed across different temperatures and different materials formats, discussions of measurement techniques were also encouraged. In addition, as a way of breaking with convention, this symposium also invited talks on novel thermoelectric phenomena. Emphasis was given to recent interests in coupling magnetism with thermoelectric transport. Sessions in this focus area included interfacial effects such as those required for spin-injection, thermoelectric effects in magnetic materials, and magneto-thermoelectric effects such as the Nernst effect. Thermoelectric transport in topological materials was another focus area. These categories will bridge the gap between the field of thermoelectric materials and other fields of electronic materials such as spintronics and quantum materials, coupling exotic and exciting electronic and thermal transport.

 

First-principle calculations of electric transport properties are a great tool for materials discovery and screening. In the past, such calculations have been very ?expensive?. Various approximations are often made. Work presented in this symposium, including the invited talk given by Dr. Jain Abnubhav and the presentation by Dr. Alex Ganose, has introduced the latest progress in this area, and the new model AMSET will eventually make calculations reasonably cheap while taking into account full electron-phonon interaction, allowing very accurate predictions on properties such as mobility without any fitting parameters. The talk given by Ms. Jennifer Coulter introduced the newly-developed ?Phoebe??a high performance framework of phonon and electron Boltzmann transport equations solver, which allows prediction of not only properties relevant to thermoelectrics but also magnetotransport properties.

The importance of having complex electronic band structures near the band edges has been increasingly recognized by researchers in this field. How to predict, or better yet, create such needed complexity still remains unclear. Several presentations shared progress in this area, including the invited talk by Prof. G. Jeff Snyder and presentations by Mr. Michael Toriyama. A proper amount of spin-orbit coupling, and topological band inversion holds the promise to create the preferred complexity.

Multiple participants shared progress in device design, many of which are for wearable applications. This included talks given by Dr. Dabin Park, Mr. Cheolhyun Cho, and Dr. Mahmut Aksit. Such work is important to the development of this field, bringing the latest progress in the field to tangible prototypes which address societal needs. Device design and manufacturing is another important aspect. The invited talk by Dr. Doug Crane shared new material engineering requirements that lead to much-improved cooling performance in certain application conditions. The invited talk by Prof. Jae Sung Son introduced research progress in making shape-conformed thermoelectric devices using a direct ink writing technique, with performances comparable to devices made from conventional manufacturing processes. The method is capable of creating miniature devices otherwise difficult to fabricate.

In addition to sharing research progress, this symposium also made an effort to create an inclusive and welcoming environment for students to learn and socialize with professors and their peers. Supported by the MRS organizing committee, we hosted an ice cream social for all participants on the evening of Wednesday, Nov 30th. Many came and enjoyed relaxed conversations with other researchers.
